newsitem.title: FINLAND: Wired summit newsroom echoes to click of mice.
newsitem.headline: Wired summit newsroom echoes to click of mice.

text.p: The traditional clatter of newsroom typewriters was replaced by the click of computer mice on Thursday as seriously wired journalists surfed their way around a U.S.-Russian summit via the Internet.

As Presidents Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin arrived in Finland -- the world's most online country -- journalists covering the event could watch them land by navigating their way around dozens of Web pages on 50 Internet-linked machines.
At least two World Wide Web sites competed to offer video or sound action piped through telephone lines to the summit press centre, and to multi-media Internet machines worldwide.

For real airport action, journalists in the press centre relied on television monitors, but a final press conference after the presidents meet on Friday will also air on the Web, via page www.virtual.finland.fi.

Such high-tech access may seem to hold appeal only for computer buffs -- nerds in their own language -- but the firms offering the services say they are on the threshold of serious business opportunities.

For the summiteers, too, the Internet is a growing platform: both presidents have home pages on the Internet although Boris Yeltsin's is currently only available in Russian. For Clinton, getting all American schools wired by 2000 is a policy goal.
Even the Clinton family's pet cat Socks has its own web site.

"On a small scale it's history in the making," said Erkki Vihtanen of state broadcaster YLE, one of the companies offering the services. "We're not advertising it too much because if everybody tries to watch it there will be problems."
Web pages tend to freeze when many people try to access them at the same time, but the summit's Finnish organisers said they had anticipated heavy demand for their sites.

"It's not as live as television but it's the next fastest thing," said Markus Leikola of A4 Media, whose web camera the Finnish foreign ministry contracted to follow the presidents around the Finnish capital.

His airport camera fed images through a portable computer, linked to a mobile phone, working at minus five degrees Celsius (minus 23 Fahrenheit). Unfortunately that overtaxed the battery so the signal was lost just as Clinton emerged from the plane.

Neither firm could say yet how many "hits" or visits their sites had received for the arrivals, but YLE's Vihtanen said hundreds of people had tried to access its site even though it is not yet fully operational.

Leikola, whose summit work is a showcase for a new Web-based realtime audio service for investors, said his company was "making money" on the summit operation, and the audio site was ready to cater for "many thousands" of worldwide hits on Friday.

Internet enthusiasts will be able to follow the presidents' news conference in real-time audio at the click of a button, and Likola said they can return to the site for some weeks afterwards to hear it again.
